awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChem: Multiscale Modeling for Fluid Separation Across Two-Dimensional Molecular Sieves and Student-Centered Course Reform
awd_abstract_narration:
Joel Eaves of the University of Colorado at Boulder is funded by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop fundamental principles, methods, and models for next-generation water purification strategies. Water security is an emerging problem that necessitates the development of new technologies for obtaining potable water. Novel, atomically thin two-dimensional crystals show great promise in water desalination applications, and computer simulations might be effective tools for computational discovery in this endeavor.  But with current gaps in both knowledge and methodology, simulations are fundamentally limited in their applicability and scope, and are unable to reliably describe how microscopic motions and interactions connect to figures of merit for reverse osmosis.  Eaves and his research group address these gaps by developing concepts, theories, and computational tools that significantly extend computational predictability and utility in modeling and understanding fluid separation across porous two-dimensional crystals.  In addition, as part of this CAREER award, Eaves is developing student-centered problem-based learning (PBL) pedagogies at the graduate and undergraduate levels, respectively.  PBL is a pedagogy that facilitates active learning by engaging students with real world problems.    Eaves plans to develop several PBL modules using some of the computational tools proposed as a virtual laboratory to encourage the kind of student-directed questioning and curiosity that characterizes scientific research.  Both the PBL modules and evaluative tools developed will be disseminated over the web.


Porous two-dimensional crystals are the ultimate limit in thin semipermeable membranes, but the same length scale disparity that makes them attractive for reverse osmosis applications also makes them challenging to describe using theory and simulation.  Using a series of test systems and models, the Eaves and coworkers study fluid separation and passage through atomically thin two-dimensional crystals in regimes of low flow, where near-equilibrium theories apply, and in regimes of high flow, where the system is intrinsically out of equilibrium and current simulation methods are limited.  They are testing the hypothesis that the hydrophobicity of the membrane, which can be altered in graphene by electrical, doping, has a measurable and controllable effect on water throughput.  In the near equilibrium case, the focus is on a stochastic theory to relate water throughput and ion rejection to spontaneous fluctuations at equilibrium and investigate the reaction coordinates and transition states for water passage and ion rejection.  Away from equilibrium, Eaves is developing novel mesoscopic simulation methods that bridge the gap between atomistic simulations and larger scale hydrodynamic and collective variables.   In addition, he plans to investigate two-dimensional crystals for water desalination applications other than functionalized, porous graphene.

por.por_cntn:
Water insecurity is a rising national and global threat. Desalination can help, but  it provides a very small amount of potable water because it is capital and energy intensive. At the heart of the process are semipermeable membranes that separate salt from water. The most interesting membranes are nanoscopic and operatre at the ultimate limit--atomically thin two dimensional crystals, with pores embedded in them thar are only a nanometer across. Computational methods used to model, simulate, and design those membranes were not accurate enough to make experimentally useful predictions. It was unclear if hydrodynamics is applicable on such small dimensions, and if so, it was unclear what the boundary conditions should be. Molecular simulations on the other hand are capable of describing the necessary nanoscale dynamics at thermal equilibrium but were fundamentally limited by knowledge barriers for describing atomistic motions in out of equilibrium fluid flows. A secondary set of scientific objectives emerged naturally from the original award, also rooted in nanoscience and also connected to emerging technologies for sustainability. The intellectual merit of the proposal provided both concepts and conceptual tools for modeling hydrodynamic flows on microscopic length scales; it lead to a better understanding of molecular interactions in these scenarios, including a better understanding of the hydrophobic effect, away from equilibrium; and a better and more fundamental understanding of carrier dynamics in photoexcited nanocrystals.

The objectives of the project were to develop better simulation methodologies for those flows, and to develop pedagogy at the University of Colorado, implementing "Problem Based Learning" (PBL). By many measures, both aims were successful and speak to the broader impacts of the research and teaching efforts funded by the award. leading to new learning methods and a new course at the university that introduces computation to graduates and undergraduates at and to new and better tools for studying nanoscale systems away from equilibrium. 

First, we addressed the problem of simulating hydrodynamic flow using all-atom molecular dynamics (MD). The simulation method that we developed employed constraint dynamics--a foundational methodology in molecular simulations--to find equations of motion that maintain a constant mass flux and temperature. This method is simple to implement and introduces a negligible computational cost compared to equilibrium molecular dynamics simulations. This method, "Gaussian Dynamics," is now part of the LAMMPS package, a popular open-source engine for MD simulations. These methods allowed us to analyze the hydrophobic effect, which is one of the most elementary water-interface interactions and is easy to measure experimentally through the wetting or contact angle. For water desalination using two-dimensional crystals, the simple question "is a hydrophobic membrane good or bad?" does not have a simple answer. The hydrophobicity is the result of both polar and van der Waals interactions, and while both can lead to similar contact angles, they have distinct impacts on water transport through pores in two dimensional crystals. 

In terms of design principles, the hydrodynamic friction that contributes to the high energy expense of desalination, decreases with increasing hydrophobicity. But in hydrophobic membranes, the backing pressures can be large, and the membrane may mechanically fail under those pressures. Polar interactions, particularly with charged atoms around the pore might lower the backing pressure, but they increase hydrodynamic friction. We provide a simple equation for computing the backing pressure for a given contact angle, which should aid in membrane design. 

During our work on two-dimensional crystals, experimental colleagues approached us with strange long-lived transients in their optical pump-probe spectra measuring electron-hole recombination in rod-like nanocrystals. Using theory, we found that these transients were the result of a diffusion-annihilation process for holes that spontaneously trap to the particle’s surface and then execute a random walk until they combine with the electron. Using density functional theory (DFT) and Wannier localization, we parameterized a model Hamiltonian and showed that the holes form Holstein small polarons on the particle surface and tunnel between neighboring sites on the particle. The mechanism for tunneling is subtle—the holes tunnel first into the dense manifold of valence band states before trapping back to the nanocrystal surface. These observations have direct impacts on how researchers use photons to harvest electrons and holes to do useful chemistry and energy transduction.

The teaching aspects of the work were to bring PBL paradigms into the classroom. As a student-centered pedagogy, the distinctions between PBL pedagogies are similar to the “flipped classroom” that has become popular in many classrooms, but avoids the pitfalls of student-directed investigation. PBL is now a regular part of my courses on thermodynamics and quantum mechanics, both for undergraduates. It also undergirds the course I created during the funded project CHEM 4555/5555, a course for both undergraduates and graduate students, that introduces students to the kinds of computational chemistry, like MD and DFT, that the project used for the research component.
